comment.author: 69716157@N03
comment._content: WWI Medal Rolls Index cards - listed as Archibald Dunlop Lemon, Lieut Royal Irish Rifles. Note on back of card states that a Miss Lemon (presumably a sister) applied for his medals. Source: ancestry.co.uk Archie Dunlop Lemon appears in 1911 Census of Ireland, living in Carrickfergus, Co Antrim. His occupation is given as 'Flax Spinner Manager' www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Antrim/Carrickf... source: National Archives of Ireland

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Archie Dunlop Lemon is shown as promoted from Temporary Second Lieutenant to Temporary Lieutenant in the Royal Irish Rifles wef 1 Feb 1915 [Sup of 8 May 1915 to London Gazette 29157 of 7 May 1915]. His address in the 1911 census, aged 36, is shown as a house at 38 Scotch Quarter, Carrickfergus Urban, where he was lodging as a boarder. 12th Battalion Royal Irish Rifles were the Central Antrim Volunteers. 2Lt Dunlop would have originally joined them while the Battalion was at Newtonards, still in basic training. 12 RIR moved to Seaford in Jul 1915 before going to France where they landed at Boulogne in Oct 1915. When 12 RIR left their trenches and lay down in no-mans land prior to the attack on the first day of the Battle of the Somme, 1 July 1916, Lt Archie Lemon was in 'B' Company commanding 6 Platoon, the left-most platoon in the battalion (alongside 9th Royal Irish Fusiliers), responsible for capturing 'Railway Sap'. Full details of the attack and his death are at www.webmatters.net/txtpat/index.php?id=78 .//

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: Ireland Births & Baptisms on www.ancestry.co.uk show he was born 2 Apr 1875 at Castlereagh No 3, Down, Ireland. He was the son of Archibald Dunlop Lemon & Ellen Workman. National Probate records show him to be 'of Edgcumbe, Strandtown, Belfast'. Probate to Maria L Richardson, married woman; Ellen Lemon spinster and Edward Lemon, solicitor. Effects in England valued at £482 1s.

comment.author: 68636946@N04
comment._content: He was educated at Methody College, Belfast. Philip Orr's book Carrickfergus, Whitehead and the Great War (Carrickfergus Museum and Civic Centre, 2010, ISBN 978-0-9543478-3-3) says he was a factory manager for Barn Mills, on Taylor's Avenue (page 12). Page 26 gives a 5 verse song that no. 6 platoon sang, verse 3 is "Then comes Lieutenant Lemon, / A man who you all know, / Will lead the famous number 6 / No matter where they go". p. 32 gives an account of the attack where he was lost. I'm Steve Diamond, searching 4 him after seeing his name on the WWI plaque in Whitehead's Yacht Club, County Antrim.
